Reason: The 'keyspace_count_warn_threshold' configuration does not directly involve any performance-related operations that are time-expensive or memory-expensive within its related code. It simply sets a threshold for the number of keyspaces in the cluster and triggers a warning message when exceeded. While having a large number of keyspaces can slow down schema-dependent cluster operations, the configuration itself does not lead to notable performance variations at the system level. Therefore, it is not classified as performance-sensitive.
